title: Example Analysis
text:
The ChickWeight dataset is a built-in dataset in R that contains weight measurements of chicks on different diets over a period of time. The dataset includes the following variables:

weight (numeric): The weight of the chick (in grams).
Time (numeric): The time (in days) since the chick was hatched when the measurement was made.
Chick (ordinal): A unique identifier for each chick (between 18 and 48). The ordering of the levels groups chicks on the same diet together and orders them according to their final weight (lightest to heaviest) within diet.
Diet (categorical): The diet type (1, 2, 3, or 4) assigned to the chick.

The data were collected from an experiment conducted by the Department of Agriculture in the 1930s to study the effects of different diets on the growth of chicks (Crowder and Hand 1990). The specific composition of each diet was:

Diet 1: normal corn diet (control)
Diet 2: corn diet with 10% protein
Diet 3: corn diet with 20% protein
Diet 4: corn diet with 40% protein

Each chick was weighed at birth, every two days thereafter until day 20, and once more on day 21 (up to 12 time points). There are a total of 578 observations in the dataset representing 50 chicks on four different diets.
The dataset can be accessed directly in R using the command ChickWeight. More information about the dataset and a codebook can be found in the R documentation.



The goal of this analysis is to explore the growth patterns of chicks on different diets over time and to determine if there are significant differences in weight gain among the diets.
The intended audience for this analysis is broad and includes students, researchers, and professionals in the fields of animal science, veterinary medicine, nutrition, and animal husbandry who may be interested in understanding the effects of diet composition on early growth in poultry.






Note



In case you were wondering, I, an adult cancer surgeon, have learned way more than any human who doesn’t work regularly with livestock needs to know about poultry feed in a very short period of time through this activity. Apologies in advance if the the nomenclature used in the following analysis is inaccurate to the field.











Table 1






Diet

n (Day 21)
% Dropout

4

9
10



Table 1. Overview of dataset showing day 0 and day 21 sample sizes per diet and percent dropout.












Table 2







Diet


Avg. Weight (Day 0, g)


Avg. Weight (Last Measured, g)


Avg. Weight Gain (g)






1


41.4


156.3


114.9




2


40.7


214.7


174.0




3


40.8


270.3


229.5




4


41.0


229.3


188.3




Table 2. Descriptive statistics of average weight gained by diet over the study period (day 0 to last measured day).












Table 3
















Diet
Est. Growth Rate (g/day)
S.E.
t-value
95% CI Low
95% CI High
Bonferroni p-value





1
6.842
0.329
20.822
6.194
7.489
9.81e-54
***


2
8.609
0.557
15.449
7.506
9.713
4.04e-30
***


3
11.423
0.515
22.181
10.403
12.443
6.56e-44
***


4
9.714
0.290
33.454
9.139
10.290
2.04e-61
***



Table 3. Linear regression analysis of weight vs time per diet showing estimated growth rates (g/day) with 95% confidence intervals and Bonferroni-adjusted p-values.

















Figure 1: This plot shows that the control diet (1) had the most dropout over time (20%) on day 21 compared to day 0. Diets 2 and 3 had no dropout over the study duration. Diet 4 (10%) at day 21.













Figure 2: This plot shows the weight trajectories of individual chicks and their diets over the study duration. There is considerable variability in weight gain among chicks on the same diet, but overall, the chicks on the protein diets (2, 3, and 4) tended to gain more weight over time compared to those on the control diet (1).













Figure 3: This series of faceted boxplots illustrates the distribution of chick weights for each diet on each day measured. There is considerable variation in weights between days even within the same diet. The starting weights on day 0 are similar among the four diets. Note that there are several low outliers in diet 1 on day 2, and diet 1 also had the most study attrition over time. Diet 4 shows an early growth advantage up until day 14, after which the weight gain drops off compared to diet 3.













Figure 4: This plot shows the linear growth curves of chicks on each diet over time with linear regression trend lines and 95% confidence intervals (shaded). While diet 4 may have had higher average weight gain in the initial measurements, chicks on diet 3 had the highest estimated rate of weight gain per day, followed by diets 4, 2, and then the control diet (1).













Figure 5: This plot summarizes the estimated rate of weight gain per day for each diet based on linear regression analysis. Diet 3 had the highest estimated weight gain per day, followed by diets 4, 2, and then the control diet (1). Error bars represent 95% confidence intervals around the estimates. All experimental diets showed statistically significant higher weight gain rates compared to the control diet after Bonferroni correction (p-value < 0.001).








In summary, this was an analysis of the ChickWeight dataset, which measured the weights of chicks on four different diets at 12 timepoints from birth until day 21: control corn diet (1), diet with 10% protein replacement (2), diet with 20% protein replacement (3), and diet with 40% protein replacement (4) (Crowder and Hand 1990).
Figure 3 demonstrates serial boxplots of the weight distribution of the chicks in each diet. At baseline (day 0), the average starting weights among all four groups are similar. Until day 14, the chicks on diet 4 appeared to have a higher absolute weight gain. After day 14, the average weight of the chicks on diet 3 surpassed that of the chicks on diet 4. This was supported by the calculations of absolute average weight gain between study start and the last measured weights, with diet 3 associated with the greatest average total weight gain (229.5 g) over the study period (Table 2). Linear regression analysis (Table 3) revealed that diet 3 (20% protein) had the highest estimated growth rate (11.4 g/day) among the diets, followed by diet 4 (40% protein), diet 2 (10% protein), and finally diet 1 (control). All experimental diets showed statistically significant higher weight gain rates compared to the control diet after Bonferroni correction (Table 3).
Notably, diet 1 had the highest dropout rate (20%) by day 21, followed by a 10% dropout rate in diet 4, while diets 2 and 3 had no dropout over the study period (Table 1). The information available about the dataset is not detailed enough to hypothesize why this may be the case, however in Figure 2, several very low weight outliers are observed in diet 1 preceding subsequent dropout, suggesting that poor growth may have contributed to chick attrition. There is no clear explanation for the single dropout (n=1) observed in data 4.
The findings of this analysis is consistent with current guidelines recommending 23% crude protein in chick feeds for age 0-3 weeks (National Research Council (1994)):



The National Research Council (NRC) requires 23% crude protein in broiler chicks aged 0-3 weeks. Source: NRC Nutrient Requirements of Poultry, 9th Revised Edition, 1994. Table adapted by (Applegate and Angel 2008)


In addition, formulations of commercial chick starter feeds contain around 18-20% crude protein (see margin).





Commercial chick starter feed with 18% protein. Source: MannaPro, Amazon.com.








Important



Since the original experiment performed in 1930 (from which the ChickWeight dataset is derived) and the peer-reviewed research (published between 1947-1991) incorporated into the NRC’s Nutrient Requirements of Poultry (1994), present-day broiler chicks are “very different from birds available prior to 1991, due in part to genetic selection as well as management practice and feed-related changes” (Applegate and Angel 2008).
Thus, current nutritional requirements may differ from those observed in this dataset and also from those recommended by the NRC. The NRC has since convened to update their recommendations with a 10th edition expected to be published in the future.





dplyr and tidyr:
count(), group_by(), mutate(), ungroup(), filter(), distinct(), summarise(), arrange(), pivot_wider(), select(), nest(), map(), unnest()
ggplot2:
ggplot(), aes(), geom_col(), scale_x_continuous(), geom_line(), scale_y_continuous(), labs(), geom_point(), geom_smooth(), geom_boxplot(), facet_wrap(), geom_errorbar()



Expand to see code used:


Code
# data important & packages:
chickwt = ChickWeight
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)

# data wrangling and analysis:
chickwt_nday = chickwt |>
  count(Time, Diet) |>
  group_by(Diet) |>
  mutate(n0 = n[Time == min(Time)], retention = n / n0) |>
  ungroup()

chickcounts = as_tibble(chickwt) |>
  filter(Time %in% c(0, 21)) |>
  distinct(Diet, Time, Chick) |>
  count(Diet, Time, name = "n_chicks") |>
  arrange(Diet, Time)

chickcounts = chickcounts |>
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = Time,
    values_from = n_chicks,
    names_prefix = "day_"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    dropout = day_0 - day_21,
    pct_dropout = dropout / day_0 * 100
  ) |>
  select(-dropout) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c("Diet", "n (Day 0)", "n (Day 21)", "% Dropout")
  )

chickwtgain = as_tibble(chickwt) |>
  group_by(Chick, Diet) |>
  summarise(
    w0 = weight[which.min(Time)],
    wend = weight[which.max(Time)],
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  mutate(weightgain = wend - w0) |>
  summarise(avgwtgain = mean(weightgain), n_chicks = n(), .by = Diet) |>
  arrange(Diet) |>
  select(-n_chicks) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c("Diet", "Avg Weight Gain (g)")
  ) |>
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

chickwt_lm = chickwt |>
  group_by(Diet) |>
  nest() |>
  mutate(
    model = map(data, ~ lm(weight ~ Time, data = .x, na.action = na.omit)),
    tidied = map(model, ~ broom::tidy(.x, conf.int = TRUE))
  ) |>
  unnest(tidied) |>
  filter(term == "Time") |>
  mutate(
    p_bonf = p.adjust(p.value, method = "bonferroni"),
    stars = case_when(
      p_bonf < 0.001 ~ "***",
      p_bonf < 0.01 ~ "**",
      p_bonf < 0.05 ~ "*",
      TRUE ~ "ns"
    )
  )

chickwt_lmtable = chickwt_lm |>
  select(-c(2, 3, 4, 8)) |>
  mutate(p_bonf = sprintf("%.3g", p_bonf)) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c(
      "Diet",
      "Est. Growth Rate (g/day)",
      "S.E.",
      "t-value",
      "95% CI Low",
      "95% CI High",
      "Bonferroni p-value",
      " "
    ),
    digits = 3
  )

# data visualization:
ggplot(
  chickwt_nday,
  aes(x = Time, y = retention, fill = Diet, group = Diet, color = Diet)
) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), width = 0.7) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(min(chickwt_nday$Time), max(chickwt_nday$Time), by = 1)
  ) +
  geom_line(aes(y = retention), linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(
    title = "Attrition of chicks measured per diet over study period",
    subtitle = "Standardized to the number of chicks measured on day 0 per diet",
    x = "Day",
    y = "Percentage of chicks measured",
    fill = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(x = Time, y = weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_line(aes(group = Chick), alpha = 0.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Chick weights over time",
    subtitle = "Raw data points with individual chick growth trajectories",
    x = "Time (days)",
    y = "Weight (g)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(Diet, weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_boxplot(varwidth = TRUE) +
  facet_wrap(~Time, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    title = "Boxplots of chick weights by day of life",
    subtitle = "Faceted to show weight distribution and variability per diet by day",
    x = "Diet",
    y = "Weight (g)"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(x = Time, y = weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 0.4) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, alpha = 0.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Linear growth curves of chicks by diet",
    subtitle = "Linear regression trend lines and 95% confidence intervals",
    x = "Time (days)",
    y = "Weight (g)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(
  chickwt_lm,
  aes(x = Diet, y = estimate, color = Diet, label = Diet, fill = Diet)
) +
  geom_col() +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high),
    width = 0.1,
    color = "black"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Rate of weight gain of chicks per diet",
    subtitle = "Estimated weight gain per day with 95% confidence intervals by linear regression",
    x = "Diet",
    y = "Estimated weight gain per day (g/day)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

text:

count(), group_by(), mutate(), ungroup(), filter(), distinct(), summarise(), arrange(), pivot_wider(), select(), nest(), map(), unnest()

Code
# data important & packages:
chickwt = ChickWeight
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)

# data wrangling and analysis:
chickwt_nday = chickwt |>
  count(Time, Diet) |>
  group_by(Diet) |>
  mutate(n0 = n[Time == min(Time)], retention = n / n0) |>
  ungroup()

chickcounts = as_tibble(chickwt) |>
  filter(Time %in% c(0, 21)) |>
  distinct(Diet, Time, Chick) |>
  count(Diet, Time, name = "n_chicks") |>
  arrange(Diet, Time)

chickcounts = chickcounts |>
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = Time,
    values_from = n_chicks,
    names_prefix = "day_"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    dropout = day_0 - day_21,
    pct_dropout = dropout / day_0 * 100
  ) |>
  select(-dropout) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c("Diet", "n (Day 0)", "n (Day 21)", "% Dropout")
  )

chickwtgain = as_tibble(chickwt) |>
  group_by(Chick, Diet) |>
  summarise(
    w0 = weight[which.min(Time)],
    wend = weight[which.max(Time)],
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  mutate(weightgain = wend - w0) |>
  summarise(avgwtgain = mean(weightgain), n_chicks = n(), .by = Diet) |>
  arrange(Diet) |>
  select(-n_chicks) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c("Diet", "Avg Weight Gain (g)")
  ) |>
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

chickwt_lm = chickwt |>
  group_by(Diet) |>
  nest() |>
  mutate(
    model = map(data, ~ lm(weight ~ Time, data = .x, na.action = na.omit)),
    tidied = map(model, ~ broom::tidy(.x, conf.int = TRUE))
  ) |>
  unnest(tidied) |>
  filter(term == "Time") |>
  mutate(
    p_bonf = p.adjust(p.value, method = "bonferroni"),
    stars = case_when(
      p_bonf < 0.001 ~ "***",
      p_bonf < 0.01 ~ "**",
      p_bonf < 0.05 ~ "*",
      TRUE ~ "ns"
    )
  )

chickwt_lmtable = chickwt_lm |>
  select(-c(2, 3, 4, 8)) |>
  mutate(p_bonf = sprintf("%.3g", p_bonf)) |>
  kable(
    col.names = c(
      "Diet",
      "Est. Growth Rate (g/day)",
      "S.E.",
      "t-value",
      "95% CI Low",
      "95% CI High",
      "Bonferroni p-value",
      " "
    ),
    digits = 3
  )

# data visualization:
ggplot(
  chickwt_nday,
  aes(x = Time, y = retention, fill = Diet, group = Diet, color = Diet)
) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), width = 0.7) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(min(chickwt_nday$Time), max(chickwt_nday$Time), by = 1)
  ) +
  geom_line(aes(y = retention), linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(
    title = "Attrition of chicks measured per diet over study period",
    subtitle = "Standardized to the number of chicks measured on day 0 per diet",
    x = "Day",
    y = "Percentage of chicks measured",
    fill = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(x = Time, y = weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_line(aes(group = Chick), alpha = 0.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Chick weights over time",
    subtitle = "Raw data points with individual chick growth trajectories",
    x = "Time (days)",
    y = "Weight (g)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(Diet, weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_boxplot(varwidth = TRUE) +
  facet_wrap(~Time, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    title = "Boxplots of chick weights by day of life",
    subtitle = "Faceted to show weight distribution and variability per diet by day",
    x = "Diet",
    y = "Weight (g)"
  )

ggplot(chickwt, aes(x = Time, y = weight, color = Diet)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 0.4) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, alpha = 0.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Linear growth curves of chicks by diet",
    subtitle = "Linear regression trend lines and 95% confidence intervals",
    x = "Time (days)",
    y = "Weight (g)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

ggplot(
  chickwt_lm,
  aes(x = Diet, y = estimate, color = Diet, label = Diet, fill = Diet)
) +
  geom_col() +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high),
    width = 0.1,
    color = "black"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Rate of weight gain of chicks per diet",
    subtitle = "Estimated weight gain per day with 95% confidence intervals by linear regression",
    x = "Diet",
    y = "Estimated weight gain per day (g/day)",
    color = "Diet"
  )

About me

title: Hi, I’m Linda
text:
The creation of this site was motivated by the Biostatistics 140.777 course at the Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health, but the content is all mine!
My name is Linda Ye, and I am a board-certified general surgeon currently completing surgical subspecialty training in Complex General Surgical Oncology at The Johns Hopkins Hospital. I am fortunate to have the support of my division to pursue a Master’s degree in Clinical Investigation during my fellowship in order to best prepare me for my career goal to be an academic surgical oncologist with clinical and research interests in hepato-pancreato-biliary (liver, pancreas, and bile duct) diseases.

title: About
text:
I’m a California-native raised in the San Francisco Bay Area but have spent most of my adult life in Los Angeles. I went to UCLA for college, where I graduated summa cum laude with a BS in departmental honors in Molecular, Cell, and Developmental biology. I then received my MD at Georgetown University School of Medicine in Washington, DC and returned to UCLA for General Surgery residency. There, I developed an interest in pancreatic diseases and surgical oncology and performed T32-funded translational research in the metabolic pathways of pancreatic carcinogenesis as well as clinical and outcomes research in surgical oncology and general surgery. I completed general surgery training in 2024 and am now a board-certified surgeon.





… Which brings me to Baltimore. I am in my final year of surgical subspecialty training in complex general surgical oncology at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, the oldest surgical training program in the nation and arguably the home of pancreatic surgery, and I am actively searching for an academic faculty position in surgical oncology!



Here, I’m (right) performing liver surgery with my program director, Dr. Kelly Lafaro (left)… apologies if you’re squeamish—the patient did well, I promise. Yay for women in surgery!


It’s an incredible honor to be here and have the support of my division to pursue a Master’s degree in clinical investigation at the Bloomberg School of Public Health during my fellowship in order to best prepare me to be an academic surgical oncologist. My clinical interest is in in hepato-pancreato-biliary surgery and complex gastrointestinal malignancies. My research interests are in the early detection and management of pancreatic precursor lesions, such as pancreatic cysts, with the goal of using data sciences to leverage cyst fluid biomarkers to improve patient selection for pancreatic surgery.



Benji (left) and Joel (right). I know exactly what you’re thinking—they are so cute, look exactly the same, and I do still have trouble telling them apart.


Over the years, I’ve understandably grown used to not expecting to have much spare time, but when not working, I like to catch up on my many years of sleep debt, watch true crime documentaries, hang out with my rescue cats (Benji and Joel—yes, like the twins in the band Good Charlotte), eat out, go to concerts, tag along on trips with my parents, and try to remember to keep up with my New York Times Crossword and Wordle streaks.
